q: "The report of my death was an exaggeration." What author of Adventures of Huckleberry Finn said this in 1897, after hearing his obituary had been published in a newspaper?
a: Mark Twain, Jack London, Oscar Wilde

q: In February 2013, what former senator from Massachusetts was sworn in as U.S. secretary of state?
a: John Kerry , Hillary Clinton, Scott Brown

q: In 1965 what city completed its famous Gateway Arch to honor the starting point of Lewis and Clark's historic expedition?
Devices such as flash drives, cameras, and printers are connected to a computer with a port called a USB. What does USB stand for?
a: Universal Serial Bus, Uniform Service Bus, Updatable System Bus

q: Out of Order is the title of a new book written by what retired justice who was the first woman to sit on the U.S. Supreme Court?
a: Sandra Day O'Connor, Ruth Bader Ginsburg, Sonya Sotomayor

q: In 1705 what English astronomer became the first to calculate the orbit of a comet later named after him?
a: Edmond Halley, David Levy, Robert McNaught

q: What major river flows through the cities of Vienna and Budapest?
a: The Danube , The Volga, The Ural

q: In 2012 the fastest-growing girl's name in the U.S. was Arya, thanks to what popular TV series based on the novels of George R.R. Martin?
a: Game of Thrones, Homeland, Once Upon a Time

q: In 1972, in gratitude for President Nixon's visit to their nation, China gave the United States Ling-Ling and Shing-Shing, two giant what?
American television audiences were introduced to instant replay on December 7, 1963, during a live broadcast of what sport?
In 71 B.C., the Romans crushed an uprising of more than 70,000 slaves led by what gladiator?
From the Latin meaning "to sprout," what process refers to new growth springing from a seed or spore?
During Hurricane Katrina, more than 20,000 people took shelter at what New Orleans stadium that is one of the largest domed structures in the world?
a: The Superdome , The Silverdome, The Astrodome

q: Which of the following is not a Slavic language?
Math question: The sum of two consecutive positive integers is 15. What are the numbers?
"All happy families are alike; each unhappy family is unhappy in its own way." Who wrote this at the beginning of his novel Anna Karenina?
a: Leo Tolstoy, Vladimir Nabokov, Fyodor Dostoyevsky

q: What country in the Indian Ocean was formerly known as Ceylan?
In July 2013, who became the first British male to win the Wimbledon singles championship in 77 years?
a: Andy Murray, Tim Henman, Lleyton Hewitt

q: What fossil fuel is the most common fuel for generating electricity in the United States?
Mercury is one of only two elements that are liquid at room temperature. Name the other.
Which of the following countries is located closest to the International Date Line and is often called "the place where time begins"?
For most of the 19th century, what song whose melody is identical to the British anthem "God Save the Queen" served as a de facto national anthem in the US?
a: My Country 'Tis of Thee, America the Beautiful, The Star-Spangled Banner

q: On July 3rd, 2013, military officers suspended Egypt's constitution and ousted what democratically elected president?
a: Mohammed Morsi, Hosni Mubarak, Muammar al-Gaddafi

q: Saber, foil, and épée are the three categories of what Olympic sport?
Math question: If the function of x is equal to the sine of x, what is the function of pi?
What Canadian city founded by Samuel de Champlain is home to the Plains of Abraham and the largest winter carnival in the world?
In 2013, what R&B legend known for hits like "Superstition" vowed to never perform in Florida or in any other state with "Stand Your Ground" gun laws?
a: Stevie Wonder , Diana Ross, Lionel Richie

q: What star located at the "handle" of the Little Dipper is also known as the North Star?
Beginning in May 1940, in a retreat that Churchill called "a miracle of deliverance," large numbers of British troops were evacuated from what northern French town?
In 2013, for its 850th anniversary, what gothic cathedral in Paris received nine new bronze bells?
a: Notre Dame , Basilique du Sacré-Cœur, Saint-Chapelle

q: Great Britain's newly revised citizenship test now demands knowledge of what legendary comedy troop known for films like Life of Brian?
a: Monty Python , The League of Gentlemen, Kids in the Hall

q: During the winter of 2012 to 2013, what city, the second largest in Massachusetts, received more snow than any other city in the United States?
On May 29, 1917, what U.S. president was born at 83 Beals Street in Brookline, Massachusetts?
a: John F. Kennedy , George H. W. Bush, Calvin Coolidge

q: What Roald Dahl book was originally titled James and the Giant Cherry?
a: James and the Giant Peach, James and the Giant Plum, James and the Giant Pear

q: What Cold War conflict is sometimes referred to as "the Forgotten War"?
a: The Korean War, The Vietnam War, The Philippine War

q: How many major islands make up the nation of Japan?
What 1852 novel sometimes called "America's first protest novel" was written by Harriet Beecher Stowe?
a: Uncle Tom’s Cabin, Native Son, Grapes of Wrath

q: What founding father was the principal author and key champion of the U.S. Bill of Rights?
a: James Madison, Thomas Jefferson, Samuel Adams

q: In most mammals, what sex-determining chromosome is present only in males?
a: Y chromosome, X chromosome, Z chromosome

q: What is the chemical formula for hydrochloric acid?
Derived from the Greek meaning "giant," what metric prefix denotes one billion?
Mount Shasta is a double-peaked volcano located in the northern part of what U.S. state?
According to the U.S. Constitution, Congress has the power to create and abolish any federal court except what?
a: Supreme Court, FISA Court, Court of Appeals

q: The capital city of Nevada is named after what American frontiersman?
a: Kit Carson , Jesse Lee Reno, John Sparks

q: When Adolf Hitler ordered the re-arming of Germany in March 1935, he broke the military terms set by what treaty signed at the end of World War I?
a: Treaty of Versailles, Treaty of London, Peace of Riga

q: The Nazis created a police state run by fear. Heinrich Himmler ran both the SS and what secret state police organization?
On November 9, 1938, German Nazis launched a campaign of terror against Jewish homes and businesses in what incident that means "crystal night" in German?
When speaking to his creator, a nameless monster refers to himself as "the Adam of your labors" in what story by Mary Shelley?
a: Frankenstein, Dracula, The Legend of Sleepy Hollow

q: Adolf Hitler assumed the titles of both Führer and chancellor after the death of what 86-year-old German president?
a: Paul von Hindenburg , Kurt von Schleicher, Joseph Goebbels

q: Hannah Arendt coined the phrase "the banality of evil" while covering the 1961 trial of what official who coordinated what the Nazis called "the final solution"?
a: Adolf Eichmann , Rudolf Höss, Herman Göring

q: In the Pirates of the Caribbean film series, ships are attacked by what type of sea monster from Norse mythology?
What is the primary instrument played by renowned musician Yo-Yo Ma?
Also known as the King of the Serpents, what giant reptile that can kill with a single glance appears in classical mythology and in the Harry Potter series?
In the second of his 12 Labors, Hercules kills what serpent creature with many heads that lives in a swamp near Lake Lerna?
From the Greek meaning "living a double life," what term describes animals such as frogs and salamanders, which can live both on land and in water?
From the Greek meaning "maker of water," what is the simplest chemical element, with just one proton at its center and one electron?
Greek for "circle of little animals," what term refers to the 12 constellations through which the Sun passes?
What man-eating monster lives with his mother at the bottom of a lake in the Old English poem Beowulf?
From the Greek meaning "membrane," what word refers to the membranes that surround the brain and spinal cord?
Derived from the Greek word for "mouth," what tiny pores on a plant leaf enable the absorption of carbon dioxide?
In the United States, what document written in 1787 is defined as "the supreme law of the land"?
a: Constitution, Articles of Confederation, Declaration of Independence

q: The UN's International Court of Justice, also known as the World Court, is located in what Dutch city?
Latin for "you have the body," what legal principle requires the government to produce a prisoner before a court and justify his or her imprisonment?
a: Habeas corpus , A priori, Ex post facto

q: What moral code and religious law of Islam is derived from the Arabic meaning "the way" or "the path"?
Name the only U.S. state with a legal system based primarily on the French Napoleonic Code, rather than on English common law.
In a string quartet, what instrument is about two inches longer than a violin and has a warmer and darker tone?
The Greek legendary hero Orpheus was celebrated for playing what ancient stringed instrument?
Comedian Steve Martin plays bluegrass music on what stringed instrument with a tambourine-like body?
The Beatles track "Norwegian Wood" features what Indian instrument that was introduced to George Harrison by Ravi Shankar?
In 2013, what American teenager won a record 6 gold medals at the World Swimming Championships in Barcelona?
a: Missy Franklin, Allison Schmitt, Rebecca Soni

q: In 2012, who became the first American gymnast to win gold in both the individual all-around and team competitions at the same Olympics?
a: Gabby Douglas , Aly Raisman, Mary Lou Retton

q: In 1988, who became the first and only tennis player-male or female-to win all four Grand Slams and the Olympic gold medal in the same calendar year?
a: Steffi Graf, Andre Agassi, Martina Navratilova

q: In both the 2008 and 2012 Olympics, who won a gold medal as the starting goalkeeper for the U.S. women's soccer team?
a: Hope Solo, Briana Scurry , Alex Morgan

q: In 1632 Lord Baltimore founded what American colony?
What large building houses the U.S. Department of Defense?
a: The Pentagon, J. Edgar Hoover Building, The White House

q: What ancient Greek mathematician and inventor developed the physical law of buoyancy?
With a population of under 8,000, what New England city is the smallest state capital in the United States?
What terrifying mythical creature of ancient Crete had the body of a man and the head of a bull?
"Peace through strength" is the official motto of an aircraft carrier named for what U.S. president?
a: Ronald Reagan, Theodore Roosevelt, Dwight D. Eisenhower

q: What peasant uprising that began in 1900 attempted to drive all foreigners from China?
a: Boxer Rebellion , Xinhai Revolution, Taiping Rebellion

q: The 2012 film The Hobbit: An Unexpected Journey was directed by what New Zealand filmmaker?
a: Peter Jackson, J.J. Abrams, David Yates

q: What is the world's second-highest mountain?
Redwoods, the largest and tallest trees in the world, belong to what genus named for a Cherokee scholar?
What English novelist of Polish descent wrote The Secret Agent and Heart of Darkness?
a: Joseph Conrad , Ian Fleming, Thomas Hardy

q: What European country with a long history of neutrality did not join the United Nations until 2002?
In 1584 what English explorer established the Virginia colony of Roanoke Island?
a: Sir Walter Raleigh, Sir William Cook, Sir John Rolfe
